entries.meaning: An incident or event that disgraces or damages the reputation of the persons or organization involved.
examples: Their affair was reported as a scandal by most tabloids.
The incident brought considerable scandal to his family.

entries.meaning: Widespread moral outrage, indignation, as over an offence to decency.
examples: When their behaviour was made public it caused a great scandal.

entries.meaning: (theology) Religious discredit; an act or behaviour which brings a religion into discredit.
(theology) Something which hinders acceptance of religious ideas or behaviour; a stumbling-block or offense.

examples: According to village scandal, they weren't even married.

verbs.description: scandal (third-person singular simple present scandals, present participle scandalling or scandaling, simple past and past participle scandalled or scandaled)

entries.meaning: (obsolete) To treat opprobriously; to defame; to slander.

examples: A propensity to scandal may partly proceed from an inability to distinguish the proper objects of censure
